description: From late Middle English, borrowed from Late Latin immersiō, immersiōnem (“dipping”).

definitionGroups.group: The act of immersing or the condition of being immersed.

entries.meaning: The total submerging of a person in water as an act of baptism.

examples: Recognising and knowing how to understand visual imagery in relation to a narrative in picture books is primarily a matter of immersion in books within a specific culture.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) A smooth map whose differential is everywhere injective, related to the mathematical concept of an embedding.
(astronomy) The disappearance of a celestial body, by passing either behind another, as in the occultation of a star, or into its shadow, as in the eclipse of a satellite.
(education) A form of foreign-language teaching where the language is used intensively to teach other subjects to a student.
One's suspension of disbelief while reading, playing a video game, etc. The experience of losing oneself in a fictional world.
